item.title: 'You are the reason I am proud': Mother of native title Bonita Mabo farewelled at state funeral - ABC News

item.title: Indigenous land rights activist Bonita Mabo dies - The Sydney Morning Herald
item.description:
Indigenous land rights activist Bonita Mabo dies  The Sydney Morning Herald

Bonita Mabo campaigned alongside her late husband Eddie Mabo for Aboriginal land rights, and continued her fight to the end.

item.title: Bonita Mabo: tributes pour in for 'mother of native title' - The Guardian
item.description:
Bonita Mabo: tributes pour in for 'mother of native title'  The Guardian

Tributes are flowing for the “matriarch of reconciliation”, Bonita Mabo, an activist and reconciliation advocate in her own right who was the wife of the land rights ...

item.title: Bonita Mabo to be farewelled at state funeral in Queensland - SBS
item.description:
Bonita Mabo to be farewelled at state funeral in Queensland  SBS

The widow of Edward “Koiki” Mabo died on Monday and has been remembered for her advocacy work in education and land rights.

item.title: Bonita Mabo’s wish was for a national public holiday – Mabo Day - Courier Mail
item.description:
Bonita Mabo’s wish was for a national public holiday – Mabo Day  Courier Mail

It's the same wish she'd make upon the stars of the Beizam (Shark) constellation in the night sky. Gentle, frail, softly-spoken, Dr Mabo – matriarch, activist, ...

item.title: Bonita Mabo family agree to state funeral - SBS News
item.description:
Bonita Mabo family agree to state funeral  SBS News

The family of indigenous education and human rights activist Bonita Mabo have accepted the Queensland government's offer of a state funeral.

item.title: Politicians pay tribute to the late Bonita Mabo - SBS News
item.description:
Politicians pay tribute to the late Bonita Mabo  SBS News

Parliamentarians and Indigenous leaders have marked the passing Dr Bonita Mabo, praising her advocacy for reconciliation.

item.title: ‘Mother of native title’ bid farewell - The Australian
item.description:
‘Mother of native title’ bid farewell  The Australian

Bonita Mabo was remembered at a state funeral in Queensland yesterday as an indigenous and South Sea Islander activist and the “mother of native title’’. Hundreds of people attended the service in Townsville for Dr Mabo — the widow of land rights campaigner Eddie Koiki Mabo — who died last week just days after being awarded an honorary ­doctorate of letters from James Cook University. She campaigned alongside her late husband during his long fight for indigenous land rights and spent 10 years on the Central Queensland Land Council. Queensland Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk described Dr Mabo ...

item.title: 'Mother of native title' Bonita Mabo dies just days after human rights accolade - ABC News
item.description:
'Mother of native title' Bonita Mabo dies just days after human rights accolade  ABC News

By Indigenous affairs reporter Isabella Higgins Mabo was the wife of Eddie Mabo and worked alongside him in the pursuit of Indigenous land rights. Just days ago she was awarded an Honorary Doctorate of Letters from James Cook University for her contribution to social justice and human rights. "It's a big loss for us all," Indigenous WA senator Patrick Dodson said. "I think Australia needs to honour people like Mrs Mabo who stood, to some degree, in the shadows of her husband, but who was the backbone and the steel that helped he and many others to continue the struggles. "A person of great ...

item.title: No fun and games for Adams - The Australian
item.description:
No fun and games for Adams  The Australian

Today marks the 25th anniversary of the Mabo decision in the High Court of Australia that recognised native title for indigenous Australians. Following in the footsteps of Eddie Mabo, the Torres Strait Islander who led the campaign for those changes, is Torres Strait rapper Mau Power. To mark the anniversary, he has released the song Koiki, written five years ago by Mabo’s daughter, Auntie Gail Mabo, as a tribute to her father, who died in 1992, five months before the landmark High Court decision was handed down. “Koiki was my father’s tribal name, the name everyone in Torres Straits called...

item.title: What Turnbull does on holiday - The Australian
item.description:
What Turnbull does on holiday  The Australian

The Prime Minister has spent time with his family - including its newest member, his four-month-old granddaughter Alice - but relaxation has been ­interspersed with phone calls to ministers. Next week he will host two international visits and the yearly cricket reception at Kirribilli House in Sydney. He will also participate in one of the country’s favourite pastimes when he attends the cricket next Thursday for the McGrath Foundation’s Pink Test. Although Mr Turnbull has an ambitious reading list for the summer and a few fiction choices, there will be a healthy dose of Australian history ...

item.title: ‘A just outcome at heart of nation’ - The Australian
item.description:
‘A just outcome at heart of nation’  The Australian

Cabinet’s initial response to the ruling, which legally banished the flawed concept of terra nullius in favour of ongoing native title, was to seek ways “continuing litigation by Aboriginal and Torres Strait ­Islander peoples seeking to establish title to particular land, with the uncertainty that would create, could reasonably be avoided”. But it also saw the implications of the ruling on some of the recommendations of the Aboriginal deaths in custody royal commission, which included a focus on the importance of land acquisition and ownership. A delicate balancing act would be required. “I...

item.title: 'Trailblazer' Dr Evelyn Scott dies aged 81 - ABC News
item.description:
'Trailblazer' Dr Evelyn Scott dies aged 81  ABC News

Among the towering figures of Australia's Aboriginal and Islander communities, Dr Evelyn Scott AO, stood proud and tall. The Indigenous educator and social justice campaigner has died in far north Queensland aged 81, and is being remembered as a trailblazer who changed Australia. She possessed a striking presence, often wearing her signature black hat, perhaps to lessen the glare of the spotlight in which she worked, even into her later years. The grand-daughter of a man brought to Queensland from Vanuatu in chains as a slave labourer to work the sugar fields, Dr Scott took to heart her own...

item.title: Koala Can't Wait to Scale His Tree and Get Back Into the Wild. Credit - Port Stephens Koalas via Storyful - The Advertiser
item.description:
Koala Can't Wait to Scale His Tree and Get Back Into the Wild. Credit - Port Stephens Koalas via Storyful  The Advertiser

“Eddie Mabo” the koala, named after Indigenous land rights activist Eddie Mabo, couldn’t wait to get back to his tree after recuperating at Port Stephens Koalas sanctuary. After checking out and conquering a tree within the safety of the hospital’s confines in early July, Eddie took to the trunk with delight and climbed deftly. Credit: Port Stephens Koalas via Storyful

item.title: Keating faced resistance on Mabo - The Australian
item.description:
Keating faced resistance on Mabo  The Australian

Although he was urged to take no immediate action, ­according to documents obtained by The Weekend Australian ahead of the release tomorrow by the Nat­ional Archives of Australia of cabinet papers from 1992 and 1993, Mr Keating instructed his department to make new native title laws a priority to give practical expression to the judgment in commonwealth law. At a meeting in the Prime Minister’s Office days after the High Court ruling on June 3, 1992, which recognised a form of native title existed in common law, Mr Keating was given a document ­titled “Mabo Options”, prepared by the Departm...

item.title: Perouse ‘victim of headhunters’ - The Australian
item.description:
Perouse ‘victim of headhunters’  The Australian

Decades later, mariners found the wreckage of Comte de La ­Perouse’s ships off Vanikoro in the Solomon Islands. Locals told them that the survivors of the shipwrecks, and subsequent skirmishes with Melanesians, had made off in a getaway craft constructed from the debris. Then the trail went cold, and remained that way for 190 years. Now a Canberra researcher has worked out what happened next. Australian National Univer­sity anthropologist Garrick Hitchcock believes the survivors were wrecked again, this time at Murray­ Island in the Torres Strait, where all but one died at the hands of head...

item.title: Mabo legacy remains incomplete 25 years on - ABC News
item.description:
Mabo legacy remains incomplete 25 years on  ABC News

Gail Mabo is a woman in her 50s now, but when she thinks of her father she becomes a child again. She remembers watching him at night as he worked away at his desk, a man alone determined to shake the very foundation of Australia. "I used to lay in bed and the door would be ajar and I'd watch him sit there in a blue haze of smoke," Gail says. "He'd tilt his glasses down and he'd look to the door to where I was and sure enough, he'd make a sign for me to go to sleep, but I would just lay there and watch him. "And then sometimes he'd take his glasses off and he'd tap on the table and he'd sin...

item.title: Who needs a statue in Australia? Guardian readers respond - The Guardian
item.description:
Who needs a statue in Australia? Guardian readers respond  The Guardian

When we asked Guardian readers which forgotten heroes they thought deserved to have statues erected in their honour, a strong thread developed arguing that no new statues should be erected; that statues in themselves were anomalies. Those that did suggest new statues often put forward strong calls to properly acknowledge Australia’s past including its impressive Indigenous history and its brutal frontier wars. Who needs a statue anyway? JCollins3 wrote: “I’m not a fan of monuments; elevating one thing over another just reminds me of what was ignored.” Another reader, Josue_Taylor, put it th...

item.title: Demertze goes down - The Advertiser
item.description:
Demertze goes down  The Advertiser

IT will be a different look Cairns Dolphins tomorrow night. Coach Mark Worthington is enjoying a beer in Hawaii as his assistant Jenny Evans takes the clipboard for the clash with Toowoomba. Naomi Moke could be back after missing the win with Ipswich while Jenny’s daughter, Teyla Evans, will miss again. Import Alli Gloyd received the QBL women’s player of the week award after her 28 points and 13 rebounds. Demertze goes down THE Marlins are expected to be without the versatile Micheal Demertze for the next four to six weeks after an ankle injury against Ipswich. The long-bomb shooter went d...

item.title: Celebrations mark 25 years since Mabo decision - ABC News
item.description:
Celebrations mark 25 years since Mabo decision  ABC News

The family of Indigenous land rights activist Eddie Mabo will lead celebrations in Queensland today to mark 25 years since the Mabo High Court decision. On this day in 1992, Mr Mabo won a legal challenge to formally recognise the land rights of Indigenous people. Mr Mabo had been fighting for his right to his land for 10 years, but the High Court ruling was handed down five months after he passed away. The ruling ended the doctrine of Terra Nullius. His daughter, Gail Mabo, was in a car with her son and "cried with joy" when she heard the news on the radio in 1992. The Mabo decision A timel...

item.title: Why it's a good time of year for The Blak Matriarchy - ABC News
item.description:
Why it's a good time of year for The Blak Matriarchy  ABC News

For Indigenous artist Gabi Briggs, her collective's second show comes at "an auspicious time". "A lot of things happened around this time of year," she told ABC Radio Melbourne's Jon Faine. "We had the [1967] referendum, the Mabo decision, the tabling of the Bringing Them Home report, which are pretty critical things that have informed my existence as an Aboriginal woman." 'Auspicious time' - May 27, 1967: Referendum sees a majority of Australians vote to amend clauses in the constitution discriminating against Indigenous people. - June 3, 1992: High Court makes a landmark decision in the M...

item.title: This breathtaking part of Australia could be your next destination - ABC News
item.description:
This breathtaking part of Australia could be your next destination  ABC News

Unspoilt beaches, brilliant blue skies, and saltwater lagoons with glimpses of whales and dugongs. Welcome to the gateway to the Kimberley in remote Western Australia — one of Australia's best kept secrets. If this is your idea of paradise then you might be a little envious of the Karajarri rangers — because this is what their open-air office looks like. "It's a nice place for a getaway and to be working out here, it's just beautiful," Petha Farrer Shoveller said. A natural paradise Port Smith is about 170 kilometres south of Broome, and could soon be seeing more tourists flock to this exqu...
